description: From Middle English ȝelp, yelp, from Old English ġielp (“boasting, arrogance, pride”), from Proto-West Germanic *gelp, from Proto-Germanic *gelpą (“boasting”), from Proto-Indo-European *gʰel- (“to shout”).

entries.meaning: An abrupt, high-pitched noise or utterance.
examples: The puppy let out a yelp when I stepped on her tail.

entries.meaning: A type of emergency vehicle siren sounding quicker and more intense than the wail.

description: From Middle English ȝelpen, yelpen, from Old English ġielpan (“to boast”), from Proto-West Germanic *gelpan, from Proto-Germanic *gelpaną (“to sound off, boast”), from Proto-Indo-European *gʰel‑ (“to call, shout, scream”). Cognate with Saterland Frisian jalpe, galpe (“to bleep; cheep”), German Low German galpen (“to scream, shriek, howl”), Middle High German gelpfen, gelpfen (“to roar, howl, bark, boast, sing loudly”).

verbs.description: yelp (third-person singular simple present yelps, present participle yelping, simple past and past participle yelped)

entries.meaning: To utter an abrupt, high-pitched noise.
examples: The children yelped with delight as they played in the cold water.
